chunks.notes: Reference to Gregory the Great's Gospel Homilies

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Debuerat etiam te beati David commonere exemplum.
chunks.english: The example of blessed David should also have warned you.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qui cum sciret se, reprobato Saule, electum esse in regnum, et eum cerneret saepe maligni spiritus furiis agitatum, et se perciperet ejus persecutionibus valde gravari, non modo se ab ejus laesione temperavit, sed ne comitum quisquam suorum in eum insurgeret inhibuit, dicendo: Quis enim mittet manum suam in Christum Domini, et innoxius erit (I Reg. XXVI)?
chunks.english: When David knew that he had been chosen for the kingdom after Saul was rejected, and saw that Saul was often agitated by the furies of an evil spirit, and perceived that he himself was greatly burdened by Saul's persecutions, not only did he refrain from harming him, but he prevented any of his companions from rising up against him, saying in the first book of Samuel, chapter twenty-six: 'For who shall lay his hand on the Lord's anointed and be innocent?'
chunks.notes: David's restraint toward King Saul

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ad postremum evangelicum exemplum quasi eo confirmans tuam sententiam annectis subdens: De illis qui eum locum tenent, et non implent officium, Dominus dicit: Super cathedram Moysi sederunt Scribae et Pharisaei: omnia ergo quaecunque dixerint vobis, servate et facite; seconda opera vero eorum nolite facere (Mt. XXIV).
chunks.english: Finally, you attach a Gospel example as if confirming your opinion by it, adding: 'Concerning those who hold that place but do not fulfill the office, the Lord says in the Gospel of Matthew, chapter twenty-three: The scribes and Pharisees sit on Moses' seat. Therefore whatever they tell you, observe and do; but do not follow their works.'
chunks.notes: Matthew 23:2-3, cited as chapter 24 in error

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Haec quidem verba veritatis plenitudine gaudent, ut pote ab eo prolata cujus sententia non incurrit in aliquam falsitatis decipulam.
chunks.english: These words indeed rejoice in the fullness of truth, as they were uttered by him whose judgment does not fall into any trap of falsehood.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed sciendum est tunc bona bene dici, cum bono animo proferuntur, tunc autem etiam bene dicta, quantum ad dicentem pertinet, perdere vim bonitatis, cum non procedunt ex fonte dilectionis.
chunks.english: But it must be known that good things are well spoken when they are brought forth with a good spirit, but even well-spoken things, as far as the speaker is concerned, lose the force of goodness when they do not proceed from the fountain of charity.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Lege dicta amicorum sancti Giobbe, qui multa bona et salubria suis dictis inseruerunt, sed sententia judicis, animum potius quam verba pensantis, reprehendi meruerunt, ita dicentis: Non estis coram me recte locuti, sicut servus meus Giobbe (Giobbe XLII).
chunks.english: Read the words of the friends of holy Job, who inserted many good and salutary things in their speeches, but deserved to be reproved by the sentence of the Judge, who weighs the spirit rather than the words, saying thus in the book of Job, chapter forty-two: 'You have not spoken rightly before me, as my servant Job has.'

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Pharisaei ergo a Domino juste reprehendi potuerunt, et tali notari correptione, tanquam a cordis inspectore, et qui immunis perseveraret ab omni contagio.
chunks.english: Therefore the Pharisees could justly be reproved by the Lord and marked with such correction, as by an inspector of the heart and one who remained immune from all contagion.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Attamen quia praelati erant, et sibi sacerdotii honorem vindicabant, cum fecisset quod suum erat, id est, horum tortuosos actus correctione dignos demonstrasset, quid nobis reverentiae talibus impendendum sit lateri sermone nos instruit.
chunks.english: Nevertheless, because they were prelates and claimed for themselves the honor of the priesthood, when he had done what was his part‚Äîthat is, demonstrated that their crooked actions were worthy of correction‚Äîhe instructs us by indirect speech what reverence we ought to pay to such persons.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Hortatur enim ut subjiciamur eis, non opera sed doctrinam considerantes.
chunks.english: For he exhorts us to be subject to them, considering not their works but their teaching.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Recordare percussionis Ozae (II Reg. VI; I Par. XIII), qui quoniam arcam Dei praesumptuose sustentare voluit, sententiam mortis illico experiri meruit.
chunks.english: Remember the striking down of Uzzah in the second book of Samuel, chapter six, and the first book of Chronicles, chapter thirteen‚Äîwho, because he presumptuously wished to support the ark of God, immediately deserved to experience the sentence of death.
chunks.notes: Uzzah struck dead for touching the Ark of the Covenant

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Tangit namque hoc exemplum eos qui incaute praelatos sibi indigne reprehendendo et despiciendo, quasi casuram eorum vitam manu reprehensionis sustentare nituntur, et Deum offendunt cujus hi qui praesunt in praelatione vice funguntur.
chunks.english: For this example touches those who rashly criticize and despise their prelates unworthily, as if trying to support their falling life with the hand of reproof, and they offend God, in whose stead those who preside exercise their leadership.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Disce item vel apostolo Paulo (Rom. XI) credens alienum servum suo domino stantem aut cadentem non judicare, et deinceps a tam superflua levitatisque plena reprehensione animum atque ora compesce.
chunks.english: Learn also, even by believing the Apostle Paul in his letter to the Romans, chapter eleven, not to judge another's servant who stands or falls before his own master, and henceforth restrain your mind and mouth from such superfluous and frivolity-filled reproof.
chunks.notes: Reference should be Romans 14:4, not chapter 11

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Navis interea hujus operis per aequoris mundialis scilicet pelagi discrimina discurrens, gubernante Christo Spirituque sancto flante, et a ventis contrariis, impuris videlicet spiritibus, sese muniente, suaque carbasa prospere in directum extendente, tandem hic tuto optatoque potitur littore.
chunks.english: Meanwhile the ship of this work, running through the perils of the worldly sea, with Christ as pilot and the Holy Spirit blowing, defending itself from contrary winds‚Äîthat is, from unclean spirits‚Äîand prosperously extending its sails straight ahead, finally gains here the safe and desired shore.
chunks.notes: Nautical metaphor for conclusion of the work

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: At si quispiam lectorum aut auditorum hoc reprehensione dignum judicaverit, pro eo quod modicis brevibusque objectis plus justo longa et grandia sint contra objecta, ideo merito sit repudiandum, quaeso suppliciter et per Dominum obsecro, ut ipse secundum capaciorem perfectioremque suae scientiae sensum, ad supra memorata objecta frustranda quae utique adversus religionem Christianam sunt jaculata, brevius strictiusque condat opus; et illud ad manus legere, et audire, vel habere volentium, sinat proferri placatus.
chunks.english: But if any reader or hearer should judge this worthy of reproof because, in response to brief and modest objections, excessively long and elaborate counter-objections have been raised, and therefore it deserves to be rejected, I humbly ask and beseech through the Lord that such a person, according to the fuller and more perfect understanding of his own knowledge, compose a shorter and more concise work to refute the aforementioned objections that have been hurled against the Christian religion, and allow it to be brought forth with graciousness into the hands of those who wish to read, hear, or possess it.
chunks.notes: Author's concluding apologia for the length of his response
